tweet: Folks in Montana have shown Washington the way ‚Äî now it‚Äôs time for Congress to follow Montana‚Äôs lead.
There‚Äôs no reason why we cannot make smart investments in working families, our children‚Äôs education, and 21st century infrastructure without bankrupting the future for our kids and grandkids.
It is possible to be fiscally responsible without cutting working folks off at the knees ‚Äî I negotiated and passed a balanced budget while serving as the President of the Montana Senate.

Spending is about priorities. 

It‚Äôs clear that Congress‚Äô priorities are out of whack.

These same colleagues that added this 2 trillion dollars of debt are now arguing we don‚Äôt have enough money to provide for our veterans, pay for Medicare, Social Security, and other programs that protect hundreds of thousands of Montanans.

They promised this tax giveaway would pay for itself ‚Äî it did not. 

In fact, it tacked 2 trillion dollars into the national debt.
My Republican colleagues passed a partisan tax giveaway that was drafted behind closed doors with no public input form Montanans.
Our debt is not skyrocketing because we are spending it on things we need like updates infrastructure or investments in education ‚Äî it‚Äôs skyrocketing because of irresponsible spending.
The bipartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget projects that this Administration‚Äôs policies will add 4 trillion dollars to the debt over the next ten years.

This week, we will vote on a bill that swipes Washington‚Äôs credit card to the tune of about 250 billion dollars over the next two years ‚Äî dollars are coming from the pockets of our kids and grandkids.
As usual, Washington could learn a lot from Montana.
Folks in Montana are resilient and resourceful ‚Äî they know how to live within their means.
As I travel across Montana, I hear from folks who work tirelessly everyday to make ends meet ‚Äî families facing the ever-rising costs of housing, healthcare, and other basic necessities.

I‚Äôm headed to the Senate floor in a few moments to discuss how Montana common sense can help solve our skyrocketing national debt.
